Now, I want to win a tempo by castling Qside and chech him. But h6 should be on my agenda.
He, righly, protects my N's possible entryon b4. This allows me to play Na5, threatening the fork check on b2. I missed it, unfortunately.

If white plays b4, I'd play Bh3. Either bxB, RxB, or Bf1 (otherwise, Bxb2 forks N and R), and I can retire the B where I like to. He is threatening h7 here, but it is doubtful he can release the B after g6, in the long run.
The idea is that if Bxh7, BxN and after g6 the B is trapped. Not so simple, though...
